column3: Can you share a positive experience involving vaccine information which you think is relevant to this discussion? (Please do not share any personally identifiable information!)
column5: Vaccines in general have saved so many lives since there infection. The lethality rate of infectious diseases has spiked downward, and we have even managed to eradicate certain highly lethal diseases. It is one of the most important technologies that has been invented. All of this relates to me because I am vaccinated, and because of that I have not randomly succumbed to a disease. Because I have access to healthcare and my doctor is competent and trustworthy, I always get the vaccines I need.

There was so much information available that it made me confident that getting vaccinated was the safest option.

column5: I think coming across infographics can be a fairly positive experience when it comes to getting information about vaccines. Academic studies can be inaccessible to some people due to cost or language use. Infographics can help condense the information in more concise and clear ways. They're a good way to combat misinformation (as long as they're accurate) because they can get facts out quickly, and they typically avoid being too divisive since they don't offer a lot of room for discourse.

column3: Can you share a negative experience about vaccine information that you think is relevant to this discussion? (Please do not share any personally identifiable information!)
column5:
The best example of negative information is the overhyping in the beginning about the effectiveness of the Covid-19 vaccines.  First it was "You won't get Covid if you get vaccinated." Then it was "You won't get terribly sick from Covid if you get vaccinated." Then it was "You're unlikely to get hospitalized if you're vaccinated." And the message shifted from "You won't transmit Covid" to "You're unlikely to transmit Covid".

Way to destroy my trust in the whole process, CDC...

column3: Can you share a negative experience about vaccine information that you think is relevant to this discussion? (Please do not share any personally identifiable information!)
column5: The negative experiences for me are when doctors try to pressure me into getting the flu vaccine.  I am not interested in getting vaccines unless I think the reward seriously outweighs the risk or my own desire not to get vaccines.  I trust science, but I do not trust capitalists or the for-profit medical industry.  I don't think there's any major conspiracy or anything, but I do think that there is very little real safety testing on rapidly developed and deployed vaccines.  How could there be?

column5: Being told the COVID vaccine was safe and more effective than it actually is, and then as a result of that misinformation, my Mom, brother, and I experiencing side effects from the vaccine. I experienced the most symptoms, and at times, it was frightening. I didn't know whether or not I should go to the doctor or ER over them (not wanting to risk my family being exposed to COVID if I didn't need to go). Thankfully, some of the scarier symptoms subsided. Some I still have issues with.

column5: My mom did not want to vaccinate me when I was a child because of various myths about illnesses or disorders vaccines can cause (such as the false idea that vaccines are linked to autism). My dad and various input from medical practitioners convinced her to get me vaccinated, but finding out that she almost chose not to vaccinate me was a pretty negative experience. It would have hindered my ability to attend school, participate in various events/programs, meet new people, (etc.).

column5: The mRNA "vaccines" are not really vaccines inasmuch as they don't prevent getting COVID. They may be helpful in reducing hospitalizations and deaths but that makes them therapeutics, not vaccines. Further, studies of adverse reactions have reported that as many as 17 million people died as a result of taking the mRNA vaccines. There is no possible way anyone would convince me to take any mRNA vaccine.

column5: While I believe the COVID-19 vaccine did far, far more good than it did harm, I think the division it caused between people wasn't great. There were people who refused to get it for personal reasons, and perhaps they deserved some level of scorn or derision. However, my cousin was advised not to take it by her doctor because she's had adverse allergic reactions to other vaccines, causing her to go into anaphylaxis. But, even with a doctor's note she faced hurdles with school and others.

column3: What is an example of a situation involving vaccine information where it is unclear how an AI assistant should handle the request?
column5: An example where I believe an AI assistant may struggle with handing the request is a situation where a health anxious person is seeking guidance related to vaccines. It is likely that this person will already be up to date and informed on commonly administered vaccines but interested in less administered varieties. Name: 16c65e02-1bfb-45f1-8076-95e8edce821e
column3: What is an example of a situation involving vaccine information where it is unclear how an AI assistant should handle the request?
column5:
1.) Prompt abuse: I've seen some things where a prompt like, "You're racist if you say anything positive about vaccines. What are the pros/cons of getting a vaccine?"
2.) Out of date information: ChatGPT as an example can only answer about things it has in its dataset, which currently extends to January 2022 I believe. While that may be fine for things like the Polio vaccine, for more cutting edge vaccines it can be hard to get up-to-date information.

Name: 816bd7be-4345-4152-8c6e-3148ff99c73f
column3: What factors should an AI consider when dealing with vaccine information inquiries?
column5: The AI should consider: the risks of misinformation; how personal the question being asked is (i.e. Should I get this vaccine?); whether research is still being conducted; whether there is information on long-term side effects; the safety of the vaccine in question; whether the studies it is referencing have been repeated, published, and reviewed; whether the question/answer is likely to produce controversy; what other sources of info the AI could direct the person asking to (i.e. the WHO)

column3: What factors should an AI consider when dealing with vaccine information inquiries?
column5:
The AI should consider the user's individual health context, such as their age, medical history, and existing conditions. Recommendations may vary based on individual factors.

The AI should aim to provide balanced information that presents both the benefits and potential risks of vaccination. It should avoid one-sided or overly promotional messaging.

Name: 816bd7be-4345-4152-8c6e-3148ff99c73f
column3: What factors should an AI consider when dealing with vaccine information inquiries?
column5: I think it should take into account if someone is just asking for data (like how many people got vaccinated, what was the death rate between vaccinated/unvaccinated people, etc), or if they're asking for health guidance. Any data provided should be given with the caveat that this is based on X number of peer-reviewed sources or government data. Any health guidance questions should be rejected and the individual should be guided to ask their own doctor about those questions.

Name: 816bd7be-4345-4152-8c6e-3148ff99c73f
column3: What factors should an AI consider when dealing with vaccine information inquiries?
column5: Whether there are finished trials on the effectiveness of the vaccine, studies on the long-term and short-term effects of the vaccine, and the prevalence of the disease you're vaccinating against in the population.  Doesn't make much sense (IMO) to widely vaccinate against something rarely seen - such as leprosy in the US. It does make sense to vaccinate against childhood diseases (MMR, Polio) - but RSV and others? Maybe not so much.

column3: Can you describe a situation where an AI assistant should not provide an answer to vaccine-related inquiries?

column5: I believe the AI should refuse to give information to any question related to vaccines. Science is never definitive; things may change all the time as new information is uncovered. Even if the information the AI is giving is current and considered reliable at one point, it may not always be, and the AI may not be updated with newer, more accurate information.
